titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Farwell Knapp Papers
titlestmt.author: by H. Dean

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday January 23, 2019 at 04:20

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Farwell Knapp Papers, largely consisting of correspondence, journals, photographs, and other papers, documents the personal and professional life of Connecticut tax lawyer Farwell Knapp. Knapp's experience as a student at Yale University and Harvard University law school are recorded, including his involvement with the secret society Skull and Bones and friendships with fellow alumni (such as poet Phelps Putnam and painter Russell Cheney). The life of Knapp's wife, Helen Bayne Knapp, and her family are also documented in the papers.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Helen Bayne Knapp (1967 and 1973) and Elizabeth Knapp Packard (2006).

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Farwell Knapp Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Farwell Knapp Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The Farwell Knapp Papers contain archival material formerly classed in YCAL MSS 116.

bioghist.head: Farwell Knapp (1893-1942)
bioghist.p: Farwell Knapp was born in Bridgeport, Connecticut, on November 28, 1893. He was educated at the Taft School (in Watertown) and Yale University where he was a member of Phi Beta Kappa and Skull and Bones. After his graduation from Yale in 1916 Knapp entered Harvard University Law School. Knapp left his studies in 1917 and enlisted in the Army, where he served with the 302nd Field Artillery in France. Knapp returned to law school after the war, graduating in 1921, and was admitted to the Connecticut Bar in 1922. The following year Knapp married Helen Bayne (1896-?) with whom he had two daughters (Emily Perkins and Elizabeth Cheney). Knapp first worked in the office of Shipman & Goodwin before he was appointed assistant tax commissioner of the state of Connecticut in 1925, a position he would hold until 1937, at which point he became a partner in the firm of Marsh, Stoddard & Day. In 1941 Knapp worked for a short time as a trust officer in the Phoenix State Bank & Trust Company before his retirement due to a heart condition. During his career Knapp also taught at the Hartford College of Law. Knapp committed suicide in 1942.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Farwell Knapp Papers, consisting of correspondence, journals, photographs, and other papers, document the personal and professional life of Connecticut tax lawyer Farwell Knapp. Knapp's experience as a student at Yale University and Harvard University law school are recorded, including, for example, friendships with fellow alumni and his involvement with the secret society Skull and Bones. Farwell Knapp and his wife Helen Bayne Knapp's family life and friendships (including poet Phelps Putnam and painter Russell Cheney) are also represented in the papers. Knapp's journals contain entries on topics ranging from his everyday family life and health to philosophical ponderings and explicit details of sexual experiences. Knapp's career is also documented in both his own writings and contemporary publications that mention his legal cases.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Farwell Knapp Papers is organized into the following four series: Correspondence, Journals, Professional Papers, and Personal Papers. Oversize material is listed at the end of the collection.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is organized into two subseries: Farwell Knapp Correspondence and Helen Bayne Knapp Correspondence. Within each subseries correspondence is arranged alphabetically by correspondent. Some of Farwell Knapp's correspondence can also be found in his journals in Series II.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains Farwell and Helen Knapp's personal correspondence dating from 1907 to 1947 and documents their relationships with family and friends.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes Knapp's essay "The Nose of the Camel"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes bookplates with Perkins coat of arms

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes inventory of Knapp's collection of erotic literature

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes black and white photographs of Russell Cheney, Phelps Putnam, Helen Knapp, Farwell Knapp, and "Nina"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Transcriptions made by Helen Bayne Knapp of journals dating 1919-1947

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Transcriptions made by Helen Bayne Knapp of correspondence between Phelps Putnam and the Knapps from 1922 to 1942. Include introduction by Helen Bayne Knapp who entitled the collection "Three Against Chance"

did.unittitle: Putnam, Phelps to Frederick Manning, typed transcripts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence and poetry collected and transcribed by Helen Bayne Knapp in 1967

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The journals are arranged in chronological order. Loose items were removed from the journals and placed in the folder following the journal or in Oversize (as noted).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains Farwell Knapp's journals written between 1907 and 1942. The series also includes two sets of typed excerpts from the journals made by Helen Bayne Knapp. In addition to journal entries the journals contain correspondence, ephemera, and black and white photographs of the Knapps as well as their family and friends.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is arranged into two subseries: Writings and Other Papers. Writings are organized chronologically and Other Papers by last name of author and, when multiple or unknown authors, by title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains writings by Knapp as well as other printed material relating to his professional life between 1920 and 1937.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is organized into three subseries: Financial Records, Legal Records, and Other Papers. The subseries are arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains personal papers of Farwell Knapp and Helen Bayne Knapp. The personal papers document financial and legal dealings, travel, and education.
